H0.text: Protons are larger than neutrons is the true statement about the parts that make up the atom.

H1.text: Electrons have a positive charge, which is true about the parts that make up the atom.

H2.text: Electrons are inside the nucleus is the statement that describes the location of electrons within the nucleus in the context of determining which statements are true about the parts that make up the atom.

H3.text: Neutrons have no charge is a true statement about the parts that make up the atom.

A4.text: Physicists assumed that the atomic nucleus was composed of protons and 'nuclear electrons'.

A5.text: The total electric charge of the neutron is 0 e.

A6.text: Its mass is slightly less than the mass of a neutron.

A7.text: The electron (e−, or β− in nuclear reactions) is a subatomic particle whose electric charge is negative one elementary charge.

A8.text: In atoms, an electron's matter wave occupies atomic orbitals around a positively charged atomic nucleus.
